Scopenote: This is a view of an exhibit case on the 1949-1952 White House Renovation in the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library in Independence, Missouri.

title: The President's Exhibit
Scopenote: This is a view of one of the exhibit cases on past Presidents in the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library in Independence, Missouri.

title: Exhibit Case, The Former President
Scopenote: This is a view of one of the exhibit cases on the role of "the former President" in the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library in Independence, Missouri.

title: Exhibit Case, Chief Executive
Scopenote: This is a view of one of the exhibit cases on the role of the President as the leader of the Executive Branch in the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library in Independence, Missouri.

title: The President's Exhibit
Scopenote: This is a view of one of the exhibit cases on past Presidents in the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library in Independence, Missouri.

title: Portrait of General Samuel R. Curtis
Scopenote: Portrait of Civil War General Samuel Ryan Curtis.   Donor: Milton F. Perry.

title: Lloyd C. Stark Political Cartoon
Scopenote: This political cartoon is titled "The People of Missouri Understood," and depicts Governor Lloyd Stark after the 1940 Missouri Democratic primary. Published in the Kansas City Journal on August 7, 1940, drawn by artist Cal Alley. The original of this cartoon is in the museum collection of the Truman Library.

title: Western Scene
Scopenote: An unidentified Western scene, possibly from around the Civil War. Donor: Milton F. Perry.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Shakes Hands with Three Men
Scopenote: From left to right, Dr. Harry Jonas, former President Harry S. Truman, Howard Cook, and William Paxton, all of Independence, Missouri, shake hands after completion of a course in "practical politics." They are in Mr. Truman's office at the Truman Library.

title: Political Cartoon, "Campaign Ribbons"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Scott Long for the Minneapolis Star-Tribune. General Dwight D. Eisenhower asking the Republican Party elephant mascot how many battles he had won. The elephant is depicted as wearing Purple Heart medals for 1932, 1936, 1940, 1944, and 1948. The lower part of the cartoon is inscribed, "To the man who gave him the fifth medal! - Scott Long."

title: Political Cartoon, "A Second Term for Truman in '48"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by James Berryman for the Washington Evening Star. depicts Harry S. Truman in the center, Senator Joseph Guffey on left, and Henry Wallace on right, all outside White House gates. In his hand, Guffey is holding a piece of paper with the text: "A Second Term for Truman in '48." A text bubble above Henry Wallace has the following text: "The Senator must be slowing down, Harry... You had almost moved into the White House before he thought that one up!"

title: Christmas Greeting
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a drawing by political cartoonist Bruce Russell of the Los Angeles Times. President Harry S. Truman is depicted smiling with a bow-tie that looks like the United States. In the lower right corner is an inscription: "A Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year to President Truman from Bruce Russell." This drawing was originally done for President Truman in 1949.

title: Political Cartoon, "Doctor of Letters"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Clifford Berryman, originally published in the Washington Evening Star on February 24, 1949. John Q. Public is presenting President Harry S. Truman with a degree of Doctor of Letters.

title: Political Cartoon, "Hammering Home a Campaign Promise"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon, entitled, "Hammering Home a Campaign Promise," by Walt Kelly. President Harry S. Truman is hammering a nail, labeled "Taft-Hartley Repeal," into a board. The board is directly in front of a bench that Senator Robert Taft was sitting on. Taft is shown leaping up, saying, "Harry! How could you?"

title: Political Cartoon, "Meeting of Our New Joint Chiefs of Staff"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman for the Washington Evening Star. Robert Taft, Thomas Dewey, and Herbert Hoover are depicted as playing with toy ships, soldiers, tanks, and airplanes.

title: Political Cartoon, "Are You a Communist?"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Paule Loring. It depicts a large bird holding a magnifying glass and questioning a rooster labeled "R. I. Red" [Rhode Island Red]. The text at the top reads, "Are you a Communist?"

title: Political Cartoon, "Button and Bows"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Robbie Robinson of the Indianapolis News. It depicts a man labeled as "Henry" and President Harry S. Truman walking away from "Campbell" and "Jacobs" Truman is wearing a button that says, "I'm Mum," and Henry is wearing a button that says, "I'm Neutral."

title: Political Cartoon, "And They Said Harry didn't have Anything on the Ball"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Harold Talburt. President Harry S. Truman, depicted as a baseball player, throws a baseball labeled "Recall of Congress," striking an elephant in the head. Having been struck, the elephant exclaims, "Oops! He threw me a curve!"

title: Political Cartoon, "I'm Mild About You, Harry"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht of the Evansville Courier, originally published on February 27, 1948. President Harry S. Truman stands at a piano with sheet music entitled "I'm MILD about you Harry" with "Words and Music by Southern Democrats" on the music stand.

title: Political Cartoon, "The Making of a Newspaper..."
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Richard Yardley, entitled "The Making of a Newspaper...If Mr. Truman 'Seized' The Press." It depicts different versions of President Harry S. Truman, seated at a number of different desks, doing various jobs such as publisher and owner, press agent, editor, city editor, music critic, copy desk, reporter, and others.

title: Photograph of a Drawing, "Surrender Hell... We've Just Begun to Fight!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a drawing by Kennelly. It depicts a donkey smiles and waves with a white bandage labeled "Nov 4, 1952" across its nose. At the top is text: "Surrender Hell...We've Just Begun to Fight!" In the lower right is an inscription: "To my Friend The Honorable Harry S. Truman President of the United States with admiration for his fighting leadership. Michael Galvin Under Secretary of Labor."

title: Map of Jackson County, Missouri by W. L. Pynchon
Scopenote: A black and white map of Jackson County, Missouri, compiled and drawn by Independence Civil Engineer and Land Agent W.L. Pynchon. The map also shows township divisions. The map dates from the mid-1800s.  From: Jackson County Historical Society

title: Political Cartoon by Bill Stepien
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Bill Stepien, originally published in 1945. Uncle Sam is dressed as a cook, holding a "Secret Cook Book", watching a turkey on the stove labeled "Atomic Bomb", and saying "How long can I keep this cooking formula a secret?" The "World" stands by watching saying "I want a piece of that turkey!" The original drawing of this cartoon is in the Truman Library museum collection.

title: "Triumph of America" by Anastasio Vargas
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a sculpture by Anastasio Vargas, entitled, "Triumph of America" and depicting a man with the American Flag. This object is in the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: Cartoon, "The Changing Face of the USA by Our Own Missouri Map Maker"
Scopenote: This photograph shows the political cartoon "The Changing Face of the USA by Our Own Missouri Map Maker," drawn by Sam Van Meter in 1960. The original drawing of this cartoon is in the museum collection.

title: A Birds Eye View of Independence, Missouri
Scopenote: This is a photograph of an 1868 drawing, "Birds Eye View of Independence, Missouri."   From: Jackson County Historical Society

title: Political Cartoon, "I Am a Progressive"
Scopenote: This political cartoon, "I am a Progressive," was created by Ole May and published in 1912. The cartoon shows William Howard Taft speaking on a stage in front of five men identified as various scandals and incidents, such as the "Ballinger scandal." the men look enthralled by Taft and hold a sign identifying themselves as "the Who'd-a-thunk-it Club."

title: Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: This is a photograph of the courtyard of the Harry S. Truman Library. Former President Harry S. Truman's office is on the left.

title: Missouri Mule Figurine
Scopenote: This Missouri mule figurine is part of the Truman Library Museum collection. It was a gift to President Harry S. Truman from the Jackson County Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. It is a replica of the ship's Annual Division Award of the USS Missouri.

title: Political Cartoon, "Presidential Visitors"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Burges Green of the Providence Journal that originally appeared on February 15, 1952. It depicts people exiting the White House with different conclusions as to whether or not President Harry S. Truman will run for office.

title: Political Cartoon, "Steeped in the Heart of Texas"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Floyd Murray of the Beaumont Journal. The cartoon, entitled "Steeped in the Heart of Texas," depicts Harry S. Truman dressed as a cowboy with a cowboy hat, boots, and a rope. He is holding a diploma from Baylor University and carrying a book, "How Texans Do It." In the distance is a sign for Waco, Texas, and he is striding toward a sign for Washington, D.C.

title: Campaign Cards
Scopenote: This is a photograph of three campaign cards for Senator Harry S. Truman's election cards to the Senate for Missouri in 1940.

title: Political Cartoon, "I'm Going to Bolt"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Clifford Berryman for the Washington Evening Star, originally published February 6, 1948. An old man labeled "Southern Democrat" tells a donkey, "I'm going to bolt!" The donkey is laughing and says, "Where to Brother?" In each corner is pictured a different presidential candidate: Thomas Dewey, President Harry S. Truman, Robert Taft, and Harold Stassen.

title: Political Cartoon, "Showing 'Em Who Carries the Weight"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jon Kennedy for the Arkansas Democrat. It depicts President Harry S. Truman and a man labeled John Q. Public standing on one side of a scale that is labeled Democratic. On the other side of the scale, which is labeled Republican, are people labeled "x-perts," radio, press, and pollsters, standing with Thomas Dewey.

title: Political Cartoon, "Extension of the Draft Act"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman in the Washington Evening Star. The cartoon depicts Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson swearing in George C. Marshall as Secretary of Defense in front of President Harry S. Truman. Originally published in 1950.

title: Political Cartoon, "No Encore"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by John Collins for the Montreal Gazette, originally published on April 2, 1952. It depicts President Harry S. Truman walking away from a piano labeled "White House piano" and carrying "The Presidency March." A donkey and Uncle Sam are peering around the opening of a doorway at Truman.

title: Political Cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht for the Evansville Courier. The cartoon depicts the "World" running down the stairs to a newspaper titled, "President Truman's State of the World Message".

title: Political Cartoon, "For Auld Lang Syne"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jacob Burck for the Chicago Sun-Times. It depicts Harry S. Truman's 101st birthday, satirically. Truman, with long white beard, stands to the right of a cake, "Happy Birthday HST-101 years", with cake cutter in hand. In bottom right corner is the text, "I said- The Boss Hasn't An Enemy In The World- He's Outlived Them All!".

title: Photograph of a Political Cartoon
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by an unknown artist. Thomas E. Dewey and President Harry S. Truman, depicted as racing jockeys  approach a finish line, labeled "November 2nd," riding a hesitant elephant and donkey respectively as J. Public jumps onto the racetrack carrying a syringe labeled "Votes."

title: Political Cartoon, "Tell Me, Alben..."
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman for the Washington Evening Star, originally published around 1948. It depicts President Harry S. Truman speaking with Vice Presidential candidate Alben Barkley, with Truman saying "Tell me, Alben,... just where did you go...... and what did you say?"  A newspaper resting on the table between them has the headline, "Sweeping Gains Made by G.O.P."

title: Political Cartoon, "No One Was For You But Me!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Joe Roberts of the St. Petersburg Times, originally published on November 3, 1948. President Harry S. Truman is congratulated by a man who says "No one was for you but me!"

title: Political Cartoon, "St. Louis Visitor"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Daniel Fitzpatrick, originally published in the St. Louis Post-Dispatch on October 11, 1950. The cartoon depicts the presidential airplane "The Independence" on the tarmac of an airport. Attached to its side is a sign reading "Hennings for Senator."  Below the plane is the text, "St. Louis Visitor." The Hennings referred to is Congressman (later Senator) Thomas C. Hennings, Jr.

title: Political Cartoon, "Out of My Way Mister!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman in the Washington Evening Star. It depicts President Harry S. Truman, with his hat and coat off laying on the ground. He is saying "Out of my way, mister....let me at 'im!" He is pushing Thomas Dewey out of the way in order to get at a man labeled "80th Congress." This cartoon was originally published in July 1948.

title: Political Cartoon, "Hats..."
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by John F. Knott of the Dallas Morning News, originally published on March 6, 1947. Entitled "Hats..., " President Harry S. Truman, wears a cowboy hat labeled "Texas," holds a sombrero labeled "Mexico," as he is handed a mortar board by a man wearing a mortar board and holding a certificate labeled "LLD".

title: Political Cartoon, "Gen. Confusion"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Daniel Fitzpatrick for the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, originally published January 15, 1951. Entitled "Gen. Confusion," it depicts Senator Robert Taft standing in front of a mirror, holding a "Commander in Chief" hat that is much larger than he is, with an ax dangling from his belt.

title: Political Cartoon, "The Searching Wind"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Dobbs. Entitled, "The Searching Wind," an elephant cowers as it looks out from the dome of the Capitol as a tornado labeled "Chicago Election" storms past.

title: Political Cartoon, "Short in a Rising Market"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Daniel R. Fitzpatrick of the St. Louis of the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, originally published in 1947. An elephant looks dejectedly at a stock ticker tape reading "Truman" unwinding in front of it.

title: Political Cartoon, "For Whom the Bell Tolls"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Daniel Fitzpatrick for the St. Louis Post-Dispatch, originally published September 22, 1942. Entitled "For Whom the Bell Tolls," two figures representing "Bottlenecks" and "Bunglers" stand looking at a bell tower labeled "Truman Report" next to smokestacks billowing smoke.

title: Photograph of a Drawing by M. R. (Bob) Evans
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a drawing by M. R. Evans, World War I comrade of Harry S. Truman. It depicts a satirical Truman family crest, with the Capitol in the background, includes representations of President Truman as soldier, haberdasher, pianist and President of the United States.

title: Political Cartoon, "Mr. Dulles Enters the Senate"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Tom Little of the Nashville Tennessean, originally published July 1949. Entitled "Mr. Dulles Enters the Senate," An elephant, representing Robert A. Taft jumps as its tail is stepped on by a foot, representing John Foster Dulles.

title: Clifford Berryman Political Cartoon, "I'm Going to Run Those Dixiecrats Out of Here"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Clifford Berryman for the Washington Evening Star that was originally published on September 5, 1948. Democratic National Committee Chairman J. Howard McGrath is standing in front of Democratic National Headquarters holding a gun and telling President Harry S. Truman, "I'm going to run those dixiecrats out of here". Truman, sitting down in front of headquarters, responds "I'm afraid they've already gone, Howard".

title: Political Cartoon by Mike Parks, "Happy Birthday -- 75th"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a cartoon drawing by Mike Parks. It depicts Harry S. Truman briskly and happily crossing 75th Street with a crowd of people following him shouting "Happy Birthday!" This drawing is part of the Truman Library museum collection.

title: Political Cartoon by Jim Ivey, "Every Boy Can Grow Up To Be President!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Ivey of the St. Peters Times, from 1959. It depicts Harry S. Truman looking into a newborn nursery looking at a baby, with the caption above the cartoon, "...Every boy can grow up to be President!" The original drawing of this cartoon is in the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: Political Cartoon, "Truman Special"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht for the Evansville Courier, originally published on June 4, 1948. It depicts President Harry S. Truman reclining on the back of a moving train, the Truman Special, as onlookers lose their signs referencing rear platform talks as the train moves away. It shows Truman dreaming of the White House porch. In the back of the train are Democratic leaders, State chairmen, and guests.

title: Political Cartoon, "Showing 'Em Who Carries the Weight"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jon Kennedy for the Arkansas Democrat. It depicts President Harry S. Truman and a man labeled John Q. Public standing on one side of a scale that is labeled Democratic. On the other side of the scale, which is labeled Republican, are people labeled "x-perts," radio, press, and pollsters, standing with Thomas Dewey.

title: Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: This is an exterior view of the courtyard of the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library. The outside of the Oval Office replica is in the center.

title: Bust of Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: This is a bronze bust of Harry S. Truman. This object is part of the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: Bust of Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: This is a bronze bust of Harry S. Truman. This object is part of the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman with His Grandson
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman walks along the sidewalk in Key West, Florida, followed by his grandson, William W. Daniel, as a crowd of onlookers watch. All others are unidentified.

title: Copy of Painting, General Lee and General Jackson before the Battle of Chancellorsville
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a copy of the painting "General Lee and General Jackson before the Battle of Chancellorsville."  It is a 1947 copy by Casimir Stapko from a painting by E. D. B. Fabrina Julio. The copy is part of the Truman Library museum collection.

title: Political Cartoon, "Who Does This Eisenhower Think He Is?"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Herbert Block. It depicts Senator Robert Taft, satirically dressed as Napoleon Bonaparte, saying "Who does this Eisenhower think he is?" to a surprised man.

title: Political Cartoon by George Lichty
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by George Lichty. It depicts a woman sitting behind a desk at a typewriter talking to a well dressed man as he walks in the room. The text at the bottom of the cartoon reads, "Here's the response to your dynamic radio speech, Senator - a letter criticizing you on your grammar, one asking for a loan, and the bill from the radio station!" The cartoon is dated September 7, 1944.

title: Political Cartoon by Charles Pearson
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Charles Pearson for the Saturday Review, originally published August 12, 1950. Six men stand conversing in a smoke-filled room as the comic caption reads "No question about it, the only man who can lick Truman in 1952 is Hopalong Cassidy. But how do we know he's a Republican?"

title: Photograph of a Political Cartoon by Ned White
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Ned White for the Akron Beacon-Journal, originally published in 1948. President Harry S. Truman is depicted crossing a finish line carrying a donkey on his back.

title: Political Cartoon, "Now the Man's Acquired a Horse"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon, "Now the Man's Acquired a Horse," by Bruce Russell of the Los Angeles Times, originally published in 1948. In the upper right corner, it depicts a copy of a 1946 cartoon by Russell, showing President Harry S. Truman sitting on a saddle, with an invisible horse under the saddle. The main part of the drawing shows President Truman confidently sitting in a saddle, riding a donkey labeled "Dem. Congress."

title: Photograph of a Political Cartoon
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a graphic that features a quote from former President Abraham Lincoln in which he acknowledges criticism, but notes that he cannot address all criticisms.  President Harry S. Truman is depicted at the bottom, saying, "That's-good-enough-for-me."

title: Political Cartoon, "We Now Return you to Washington"
Scopenote: This is a photo of a political cartoon by Herbert Block (Herblock) for the Washington Post, originally published in July 1948. President Harry S. Truman is depicted dragging an elephant away from Philadelphia, toward the Capitol Building, as a radio announcer runs alongside.

title: Political Cartoon by Jim Berryman
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman for the Washington Evening Star, originally published in 1944. Senator Harry S. Truman holds a document which reads "Army wastes skills of 90% of draftees. He is looking at a man holding a carpetbag labeled "late summer session." The man tells Truman, "The army's a piker, Senator... looks like I'm going to be wasting 100% of my skill for awhile!" They are standing next to a board labeled "Truman Committee Reports".  The man is holding a paper labeled "Congressional Calendar" reading "No business in sight" and "waiting for reconversion bills."

title: Political Cartoon, "And Howe!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon. President Harry S. Truman and Governor Thomas Dewey race around a running track with the finish line in sight.  The caption reads, "Mr. Thomas E. Dewey is reported to be a 15 to 1 favourite for the United States Presidency.  Trier Truman: 'Favourites can lose you know, Tom.'"

title: Political Cartoon, "-- and on Two Legs"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht of the Evansville Courier, originally published on November 3, 1948. It depicts Uncle Sam as he reaches to shake the hand of President Harry S. Truman, portrayed as a jockey riding a donkey, as he defeats Thomas Dewey, who is falling off of his elephant. Leg bandages indicate the donkey has been injured by the "Wallace Vote" and the "Thurmond Vote," and men who have placed bets stand angered and confused along the track.

title: Political Cartoon by LeBaron Coakley
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by LeBaron Coakley. Judge Pine stands behind his desk, positioned in front of the Lincoln Memorial and, pointing a finger at President Abraham Lincoln, says "You, Sir, are unconstitutional!" as the Emancipation Proclamation is seen in the background.

title: Political Cartoon, "Maybe I Was Better Off When I Wasn't Invited"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Herb Block in the Washington Post, originally published in 1951. Entitled "Maybe I was Better Off When I Wasn't Invited," an elephant is distraught when presented with a "$16 Billion Tax Program" by President Harry S. Truman and a donkey.  On the wall, a sign reads "White House Bipartisan Tax Conference."

title: Watercolor of Truman Library Exterior Plans
Scopenote: This photograph shows a watercolor of artist Egan Ray Gleason's concept of the Truman Library's exterior. The original watercolor is in the Museum collection.

title: "Triumph of America" by Anastasio Vargas
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a sculpture by Anastasio Vargas, entitled, "Triumph of America" and depicting a man with the American Flag. This object is in the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: Political Cartoon, "'I'm Just Adding a Balcony'"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman and published around 1951 in the Washington Evening Star. The photo shows Harry Truman building a balcony out of wood planks that read "'51 Defense effort" and "'48 Democratic platform." He says "Of course I'm not giving up the old stand--I'm just adding a balcony!"

title: Political Cartoon, "A Hopeless Undertaking"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon from William A. Rogers and published by Harper's Weekly on October 9th, 1880. The cartoon shows a man in diving equipment at the ocean floor, attempting to rescue a ship called "Democracy" that says "Sunk 1860." The diver is attached to a boat full of men flying the Vermont flag. In the background, a man is swimming next to a ship called the "Republic." A description at the bottom of the illustration reads: "Hancock (who has been sent down to see what can be done to raise an ancient wreck). 'If I only had this old hulk above water, and on the White House dry-dock, she might be made ready for action again.'"

title: Political Cartoon, "The Rubber Stamp Convention"
Scopenote: This cartoon, "The Rubber Stamp Convention," was created by an unidentified artist and published in 1940. The cartoon shows the hand of F.D.R. stamping an "F.D.R." stamp onto a paper that shows a caricature of himself.

title: Political Cartoon, "Vindicated--Sweeping Accusations"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Thomas Nast and published in Harper's Weekly on June 22nd, 1872. The cartoon shows Ulysses S. Grant shaking hands with a man indoors as a woman sweeps arrows of "malice," "plunder," and "greed" off his doorstep.

title: Political Cartoon, "Extension of the Draft Act"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman in the Washington Evening Star. The cartoon depicts Chief Justice Fred M. Vinson swearing in George C. Marshall as Secretary of Defense in front of President Harry S. Truman. Originally published in 1950.

title: Exterior Picture of Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: This is an exterior view of the entrance of the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: Missouri Mule Figurine
Scopenote: This Missouri mule figurine is part of the Truman Library Museum collection. It was a gift to President Harry S. Truman from the Jackson County Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. It is a replica of the ship's Annual Division Award of the USS Missouri.

title: Certificate of Imperium Neptuni Regis
Scopenote: The certificate of Imperium Neptuni Regis was given to President Harry S. Truman while he was on board the USS Missouri as part of the Crossing the Equator ceremonies when he returned to the United States from a trip to Brazil. This object is in the Truman Library Museum Collection.

title: Political Cartoon, "Love Me, Love My Balcony!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Gib Crockett, originally published in the Washington Evening Star. It depicts President Harry S. Truman standing on the newly-constructed balcony of the White House. Truman is depicted as saying, "Love Me, Love My Balcony!" and is holding a piece of paper, which reads: Four Fine Arts Commissioners who opposed balcony have been replaced. This cartoon was originally published on June 21, 1948.

title: Researcher Randolph Yeager in the Research Room of the Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: Truman Library Director Dr. Philip C. Brooks (left) with Randolph Yeager (right) in the Research Room of the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: Political Cartoon, "A Returning Traveler Exhibits a Rare Jewel!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman in the Washington Evening Star. President Harry S. Truman displays the good will he received from a trip abroad to Uncle Sam.

title: Political Cartoon, Taft-Hartley
Scopenote: This is a photograph of the second of two panels of a political cartoon by McCoy. It depicts an elephant labeled GOP (Grand Old Party) being blown up by a cannon labeled "Taft-Hartley Law."

title: Political Cartoon, "It was Right Here When I Left for St. Louis!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman for the Washington Evening Star. President Harry S. Truman is standing behind a desk, saying, "It was right here when I left for St. Louis!" Standing beside him is William Boyle (left) and John Steelman (right), sweating and looking through a file cabinet and emptying a trash container. Kneeling on the floor are Charles Ross and General Harry Vaughan.  Vaughan is pointing at a small creature coming out of a hole in the floor.

title: Political Cartoon, "Traveling Salesman"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Paule Loring of the Providence, Rhode Island Bulletin. It depicts a man walking up a sidewalk, carrying two bags. He is coming out of a car labeled "J. Howard McGrath." One of the bags is labeled "continuation of war time price support." The mailbox is labeled "John Farmer, Des Moines."

title: Political Cartoon, "Are You a Communist?"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Paule Loring. It depicts a large bird holding a magnifying glass and questioning a rooster labeled "R. I. Red" [Rhode Island Red]. The text at the top reads, "Are you a Communist?"

title: Political Cartoon by Charles E. Martin
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Charles E. Martin. It depicts a piano being moved into, or out of a moving van parked next to the curb at the White House.

title: Political Cartoon, Taft-Hartley
Scopenote: This is a photograph of the first of two panels of a political cartoon by McCoy. It depicts an elephant labeled GOP (Grand Old Party) hitched in front of a smoldering cannon labeled "Taft-Hartley Law."

title: Political Cartoon, "Truman Special"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht for the Evansville Courier, originally published on June 4, 1948. It depicts President Harry S. Truman reclining on the back of a moving train, the Truman Special, as onlookers lose their signs referencing rear platform talks as the train moves away. It shows Truman dreaming of the White House porch. In the back of the train are Democratic leaders, State chairmen, and guests.

title: Political Cartoon, "Crowding into the Picture"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht for the Evansville Courier, originally published on May 27, 1948. Depictions of a donkey and an elephant are joined by symbols of the month of June including a bride, a graduate, a child preparing for vacation and President Harry S. Truman saying "my cross country trip. "

title: Illustration of Harry S. Truman as an American Legion Member
Scopenote: This is a photograph of an illustration by Joseph C. Sewell. The illustration depicts Truman as a member of the American Legion.  The illustration also includes information concerning Truman's life as well as drawings of President Truman at work and a farm scene with an outline of the state of Missouri.

title: Political Cartoon by Jim Berryman
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman for the Washington Evening Star. President Harry S. Truman is standing inside a grandstand and grabs hold of a figure labeled "Senate Opposition." Clark Griffith runs toward the President, holding a baseball labeled "'49 Major League Opening Pitch," saying "No, no... Mr. President THIS is what you're supposed to throw out!"

title: Political Cartoon, "The Man in the Saddle"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Bruce Russell for the Los Angeles Times, originally published in 1946. Entitled "The Man in the Saddle," President Harry S. Truman sits in a saddle appearing to be in midair because there is nothing beneath him. In the background is the Capitol Building and Washington Monument. Mr. Truman has a quizzical look on his face.

title: Reuben Wallace Home in Independence, Missouri
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a drawing of the Reuben Wallace home in Independence, Missouri at 825 Main Street. Reuben Wallace was a grand-uncle of Bess Wallace Truman.  From: Jackson County Historical Society.

title: Political Cartoon by Herc Ficklen, "Old Ghosts Never Die"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Herc Ficklen, originally published in the Dallas News in 1953. It depicts a jack-o-lantern, labeled "Chambers Documents," in a field, with a trail of a ghost coming out of it. The ghost is behind former President Harry S. Truman, tapping him on the shoulder. The original drawing of this cartoon is in the Truman Library museum collection.

title: Jim Berryman Political Cartoon, "Boss, Can You Spare Me a Few Minutes?"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman for the Washington Evening Star, originally published around 1948. It depicts President Harry S. Truman stepping off of a plane being greeted by a nervous Democratic National Committee Chairman J. Howard McGrath saying "Boss, can you spare me a few minutes?" while he holds paper marked "Virginia Seceding, Other States Revolting, Wallace Wins in the Bronx".

title: Copy of Statement by Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: This photograph shows a copy of a statement by former President Harry S. Truman regarding his presidential library.

title: Political Cartoon, "Progressive Republicans"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Matthew Caine and published around 1908. The cartoon shows a caricature of Theodore Roosevelt preparing to hammer a rod that reads "Progressives" on one side and "Republicans" on the other. Each of three horseshoes on the ground has a note attached to it. The notes read "Progressive principles," "recall of judicial decisions," and "state-wide primary."

title: Political Cartoon, "We're Making Progress, General..."
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman and published in the Washington Evening Star in 1947. The cartoon shows President Harry S. Truman and Secretary of State George Marshall sitting at a desk, each holding up a different newspaper headline that features the phrase "U.S. is wrong." President Truman says "We're making progress, General...we've finally gotten Britain and Russia to agree on something!"

title: Political Cartoon, "Crowding into the Picture"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Karl Kae Knecht for the Evansville Courier, originally published on May 27, 1948. Depictions of a donkey and an elephant are joined by symbols of the month of June including a bride, a graduate, a child preparing for vacation and President Harry S. Truman saying "my cross country trip. "

title: Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: This is a view of a portion of the courtyard of the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library. Former President Harry S. Truman's office can be seen on the right, and the exterior of the Oval Office replica is on the left.

title: Picture of Street Exit of Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: This is the front lawn and driveway of the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library in Independence, Missouri.

title: Flag outside of the Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: This is a picture of a flag that is flying outside of the front entrance of the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: Campaign Poster of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Vice President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Unidentified men are hanging a campaign poster for the 1944 election featuring President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Vice Presidential candidate Harry S. Truman. All are unidentified.

title: Lawrence, Kansas Scene
Scopenote: Lawrence, Kansas scene after the raid by William Quantrill in August, 1863, during the Civil War.  Donor: Milton F. Perry.

title: Map of Independence, Missouri
Scopenote: This is a photograph taken in 1964 of a historical map of Independence, Missouri.
Institutional Creator: Jackson County Historical Society, Independence, MO

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Converses with Three Men
Scopenote: From left to right, Dr. Harry Jonas, former President Harry S. Truman, Howard Cook, and William Paxton, all of Independence, Missouri, shake hands after completion of a course in "practical politics." They are in Mr. Truman's office at the Truman Library.

title: Political Cartoon, "Even If the Bridge is in Your Home District, Senator..."
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by George Lichty. It depicts Senator "Fig Newton" standing in the back of a car, speaking to a group of people, while in the background, an Army Bridge is being built. The cartoon caption is: "Even if they bridge is in your home district, Senator, I don't think you should take credit for it in your campaign speeches!"

title: Political Cartoon, "Overdoing the Razzle-Dazzle"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman for the Washington Evening Star. President Harry S. Truman is depicted as a football player and telling Thomas Dewey, Robert Taft, Earl Warren, and Harold Stassen that one of them has to carry the ball, which is labeled "G.O.P. [Republican] Nomination '48". Created by Jim Berryman.

title: Print, "Evolution"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a colored print entitled "Evolution" by H. Gardner. It depicts the transformation from a Second Lieutenant into a whistling wolf.

title: Political Cartoon, "Said the Man from Missouri to the Man from Michigan"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Arthur B. Poinier of the Detroit Free Press. It depicts President Harry S. Truman telling Governor G. Mennen Williams of Michigan about Election Day. Created by Poinier.

title: Political Cartoon, "And Some of the Boys Were Selling Him Short!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Harold M. Talburt. The cartoon depicts a donkey watching President Harry S. Truman's "stock" charted on a graph, with the top point of the graph shown as a rocket. The low point on the graph is labeled "Lewis."

title: Political Cartoon, "Please Make Me Stop This!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Clifford Berryman for the Washington Evening Star, originally published June 29, 1949. President Harry S. Truman asked to enforce the economy as Congress is hitting itself on the head with a mallet labeled "swollen appropriations."

title: Political Cartoon, "News!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Harold M. Talburt. It depicts Harry S. Truman biting a dog next to a fire hydrant. At the bottom is an inscription: "Watch your vest Mr. President- you know darn well he isn't house broken!- Best Wishes, H.M Talburt."

title: Political Cartoon, "Shape of Things to Come"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jim Berryman published in the Washington Evening Star on August 14, 1946. President Harry S. Truman, wearing an academic robe and mortarboard hat, delivers an address saying "...So, addressing you on behawf of my illustrious compatriot, I shall endeavor to refrain from indulging in cawsting aspersions of a vulgar nature..." His speech is resting on a stack of books labeled "Public Speaking" and "Higher Level Oratory." In the wastebasket is a piece of paper with "Give 'em H--- Technique" printed on it.

title: Political Cartoon, "Plantada"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Carmelo Filardi, originally published in El Mundo in San Juan, Puerto Rico. A female representation of Puerto Rico appeals, brokenhearted, to President Harry S. Truman.

title: Political Cartoon, "Gratitude"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Harold Talburt. Two men, labeled "Phony Liberals" and "G.O.P. Politicians" cry "Save Us" as they lean out of a building being burned by the "R.R. Strike" and "Coal Strike" as President Harry S. Truman runs toward the building with a ladder. Two weeks later, the two men jump on and beat President Truman yelling, "You used the wrong kind of ladder!"

title: Political Cartoon by Victor Gillam, "Back to Work"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Victor Gillam, originally published in 1898. Entitled "Back to Work," Uncle Sam farms his land as he is pulled by an elephant and a donkey. A sign outside of an adjacent factory reads: "For Sale: Grain to Feed the World" and the caption reads: "Uncle Sam -- 'Having satisfactorily settled that little difficulty with Spain, I will now get to work on the great grain harvest of 1898.'"

title: Political Cartoon, "Can't Change that Old Odor"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Jack Knox of the Memphis Commercial Appeal, originally published on January 16, 1942. Entitled "Can't Change That Old Odor," a skunk representing "Milan Irregularities" sprays itself with "War Dep't Perfume" as a bullet labeled "Truman Report" strikes the perfume bottle.

title: Political Cartoon, "Truman for President, Haderlein for Postmaster"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Len. The cartoon depicts copies of Weber's Independent Newspaper riding on a car labeled the "TRUMAN BANDWAGON" under a sign "TRUMAN for PRESIDENT."  The text at the bottom of the cartoon reads, "In March, 1948, cagey Illinois politicians were agog when a 10X40 foot billboard touting Truman for president was hoisted above representative Charles H. Weber's Chicago gas station. In June faint-hearted citizens and Democratic workers were revived by a shot in the voting arm when more than 40,000 copies of Weber's Independent Newspapers carrying the above cartoon were distributed by mail."

title: Political Cartoon by Burris Jenkins, "She Ain't What She Used To Be!"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon, entitled "She Ain't What She Used to Be!" by Burris Jenkins, originally published in the New York Journal-American. It depicts a donkey labeled "NEW DEAL" looking weak while Sam Rayburn, Alben Barkley, and J. Howard McGrath try to help the horse while other men try to harm the horse. James Farley is standing in the corner. Harry S. Truman labeled "LIGHT HORSE HARRY" approaches the horse in a jockey uniform and carrying a saddle. The original drawing of this cartoon is in the Truman Library museum collection.

title: Gib Crockett Political Cartoon, "Tourist Season"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon by Gib Crockett, originally published in the Washington Evening Star on June 22, 1953. It depicts former President Harry S. Truman, in a Hawaiian shirt, standing outside the fence surrounding the White House, taking a picture of it. This original cartoon is in the museum collection of the Truman Library.

title: Greek Child Statue
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a figurine of a child, entitled, "The Spirit of Peace of Freedom." It depicts a Greek child dressed in the uniform of a Greek Evzone guard. It is part of the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: Political Cartoon, "Historical Moves"
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a political cartoon, "Historical Moves," by Karl Kae Knecht and published in the Evansville, Indiana Courier on November 22nd, 1948. This cartoon shows President Harry S. Truman and Secretary of State George Marshall walking into the White House with luggage as movers work around them. The movers are bringing items from the White House, such as a piano, to the "Lee House Blair House, temporary home of the President" across the street. Margaret is seen in the Blair House window. One man working with the movers says "Start repairs as soon as they move."

title: Aerial View of the Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: This is an aerial view of the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: Exterior View of Parking Lot
Scopenote: Cars are parked in a parking lot outside of the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: Chair With Grinnell College Seal
Scopenote: This is a photograph of an armchair with the crest from Grinnell College at the top of the back of the chair. It was given to former President Harry S. Truman upon his visit to the college. This object is in the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: USS Missouri Silver
Scopenote: This photograph shows part of a silver service from the USS Missouri on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: USS Missouri Silver
Scopenote: This photograph shows part of a silver service from the USS Missouri on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: Theodore Roosevelt Portrait
Scopenote: This photograph depicts a portrait drawing of President Theodore Roosevelt by Carl J. Becker on display at the Harry S. Truman Library. This object is in the Truman Library Museum collection.

title: USS Missouri Silver
Scopenote: This photograph shows part of a silver service from the USS Missouri on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: USS Missouri Model
Scopenote: This photograph depicts a model of the USS Missouri on display at the Harry S. Truman Library. This object is part of the Truman Library museum collection.

title: USS Missouri Silver
Scopenote: This photograph shows part of a silver service from the USS Missouri, including a punch bowl and cups, on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: USS Missouri Silver
Scopenote: This photograph shows part of a silver service from the USS Missouri, including a punch bowl and cups, on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: USS Missouri Plaque
Scopenote: This photograph depicts a plaque from the U.S.S. Missouri on display at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: USS Missouri Silver
Scopenote: This photograph shows part of a silver service from the USS Missouri, including a punch bowl and cups, on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Presidential Library.

title: USS Missouri Surrender Plaque
Scopenote: This photograph depicts a replica of the surrender plaque from the deck of the USS Missouri marking the spot where Japan signed the surrender document ending World War II. It was on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: Painting Of the USS Missouri
Scopenote: This photograph depicts a painting of the USS Missouri by Paul Strayer on display at the Harry S. Truman Library. This painting is in the museum collection of the Truman Library.

title: USS Missouri Model
Scopenote: This photograph depicts a model of the USS Missouri on display at the Harry S. Truman Library. This object is part of the Truman Library museum collection.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson Staff Tour Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman gives a tour of the Harry S. Truman Library to the representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson who came to brief Mr. Truman. From left to right: former President Truman; Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau; General Marshall Carter, Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency; Charles Murphy, Under Secretary of Agriculture; and Michael Forrestal, member of the staff of National Security Council.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson Tour the Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman and Dr. Philip C. Brooks give a tour of the Harry S. Truman Library to the Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson. From left to right: Truman Library Director Dr. Philip Brooks; General Marshall Carter, Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency; former President Truman; Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau; Charles Murphy, Under Secretary of Agriculture; and Michael Forrestal, member of the staff of National Security Council. They are in the main lobby of the Library.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson Tour the Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman and Dr. Philip C. Brooks give a tour of the Harry S. Truman Library to the Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson. Standing from left to right are: Truman Library Director Dr. Philip C. Brooks; Michael Forrestal, member of the staff of National Security Council; former President Truman; Charles Murphy, Under Secretary of Agriculture; Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau; and General Marshall Carter, Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson Meet with Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson gather in the Conference Room at the Harry S. Truman Library, in Independence, Missouri, to brief former President Harry S. Truman on current affairs. From left to right: General Marshall Carter (left), Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency; Michael Forrestal (center), member of the staff of National Security Council; and Former President Truman (right) pose for a picture.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson Take a Tour
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman  gives a tour of the Harry S. Truman Library to the representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson that came to brief him on national issues. From left to right: unidentified man; unidentified man (mostly obscured by Mr. Truman); former President Truman; Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau; General Marshall Carter, Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency; and Michael Forrestal, member of the staff of National Security Council. They are viewing a picture of President Truman with Prime Minister Winston Churchill.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Plays the Piano
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman plays the piano in the auditorium of the Harry S. Truman library. Two representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson, Michael Forrestal (right), member of the staff of National Security Council, and Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau, are watching him play. Charles Murphy, Under Secretary of Agriculture, can be seen below the stage.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson Meet with Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson gather in the Conference Room at the Harry S. Truman Library, in Independence, Missouri, to brief former President Harry S. Truman on current affairs. From left to right: Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau; General Marshall Carter, Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency; Michael Forrestal, member of the staff of National Security Council; and former President Truman.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson with Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson gather in the Conference Room at the Harry S. Truman Library, in Independence, Missouri, to brief former President Harry S. Truman on current affairs. From left to right: Charles Murphy, Under Secretary of Agriculture; Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau; General Marshall Carter, Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency; Michael Forrestal, member of the staff of National Security Council, and former President Truman.

title: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson Meet with Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Representatives of President Lyndon B. Johnson gather in the Conference Room at the Harry S. Truman Library, in Independence, Missouri, to brief former President Harry S. Truman on current affairs. From left to right: Charles Murphy, Under Secretary of Agriculture; Elmer Staats, Deputy Director of the Budget Bureau; General Marshall Carter, Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency; Michael Forrestal, member of the staff of National Security Council, and former President Truman. An unidentified man on the lower left side is filming the meeting.

title: Representatives from President Lyndon B. Johnson at the Truman Library

Charles Murphy, Under Secretary, is bending down to sign the guest book.

title: Truman Library Employees Sit in an Office
Scopenote: Employees at the Harry S. Truman Library are sitting in an office. J.R. Fuchs is facing the camera. On the left is Curator Milton Perry, and on the right is archivist Phil Lagerquist, who is reading a document.

title: Woodrow Wilson Foundation Medal
Scopenote: President Harry S. Truman received the Woodrow Wilson Award from the Woodrow Wilson Foundation. This object is in the museum collection of the Truman Library.

title: Portrait of Helen C. Luckey
Scopenote: Harry S. Truman Library employee, Helen Luckey,  was awarded secretary of the year.

title: Certificate to Major General Michael Gavin
Scopenote: This is a photograph of a certificate given to Major General Michael Galvin as Commanding General of the 94th Command Headquarters, Divisional.

title: Bust of President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: This is a bust of President Harry S. Truman by Pedro Pauselli. Truman's head is balancing on-top of a globe, with the word "PAX" in raised lettering across the Pacific and Atlantic Ocean on either side of North and South America. This object is in the museum collection of the Truman Library.

title: Cabinet Chair of President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: This is the chair used by President Harry S. Truman in the Cabinet Room at the White House, purchased and given to him by his Cabinet officers. This object is in the museum collection of the Truman Library.

title: Helen C. Luckey and James Fuchs
Scopenote: Helen C. Luckey is being photographed after receiving the secretary of the year award. Luckey was an employee at the Harry S. Truman Library. Luckey (right) is standing next to James Fuchs (left), an archivist at the Harry S. Truman Library.

title: Group Visits Harry S. Truman Library

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Speaking

title: Group Photo with Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: Herbert Sugden (right), Former President Harry S. Truman (center), and James Patton (left) are all shaking hands with one another outside Mr. Truman's office at the Truman Library. They attended a tribute luncheon hosted by the Farmers of America in honor of Mr. Truman.

title: General View of Farmers of America Tribute Luncheon
Scopenote: Unidentified guests sit at the Farmers of America tribute luncheon in honor of former President Harry S. Truman, held at the RLDS (Community of Christ) Auditorium in Independence, Missouri.

Scopenote: Howard Cowden is speaking at the tribute luncheon for former President Harry S. title: Former President Harry S. Truman Looks at Stamps
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (center) and Averell Harriman (left) are looking at a stamp collection album, during a tribute luncheon held in Mr. Truman's honor at the RLDS (Community of Christ) Auditorium. The luncheon was hosted by the Farmers of America. Mrs. Bess Truman (third from left) is sitting at the table with the two men. All others are unidentified.

title: Howard Cowden Giving a Speech
Scopenote: Howard Cowden (standing behind podium) delivers remarks at a tribute luncheon in honor of former President Harry S. Truman, hosted by the Farmers of America and held at the RLDS (Community of Christ) Auditorium in Independence, Missouri. Also visible in this photo is (from left to right) Mrs. Bess W. Truman, the Wool Queen, and James Patton (wearing eye patch). All others are unidentified.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Attends Tribute Luncheon
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman attends a tribute luncheon in his honor, hosted by the Farmers of America at the RLDS (Community of Christ) Auditorium. title: Former President Harry S. Truman Attends Luncheon

title: General View of Farmers of America Tribute Luncheon

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Meets with Guests

The luncheon was hosted by the Farmers of America. Among those present are Keith Cowden, Rex Long, John Eidam, Guy Cowden, Mrs. Keith Cowden, Jess Stratton, Mrs. Stratton, Mrs. Howard Cowden, James A. Lewis, Howard Cowden (fifth from right), Herb Plambeck, Gene Cowden, and Howard Hutchinson. This photograph was taken outside Mr. Truman's office at the Truman Library.

title: Head Table at Harry S. Truman Tribute Luncheon
Scopenote: Guests at the head table at a tribute luncheon for former President Harry S. Truman are standing behind their chairs. From left to right: unidentified, former President Truman, former First Lady Bess W. Truman, Howard Cowden, James Patton, Herbert Sugden, two unidentified men.

title: General Table Arrangements
Scopenote: In May of 1964, the Farmers of America honored former President Harry S. Truman with a luncheon at the RLDS (Community of Christ) auditorium. Here are the table arrangements at the celebration.

title: Birthday Cake for Former President Harry S. Truman
Scopenote: The Farmers of America honored former President Harry S. Truman with a tribute luncheon held at the RLDS (Community of Christ) Auditorium in Independence, Missouri. This is the 80th birthday cake that was at the celebration.

title: Howard Cowden Speaking at Tribute Luncheon

title: Group from Japan at Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: A group of survivors of the atomic bombings of Japan and others view and photograph a replica of the statue commemorating the flag raising at Iwo Jima that is on exhibit at the Truman Library. All are unidentified.

Scopenote: A group of unidentified women sit in chairs at the Harry S. Truman Library. These women were survivors of the atomic bombings of Japan who traveled to the Harry S. Truman Library to hear former President Harry S. Truman give a speech.

title: Japanese Group in Auditorium
Scopenote: A group of survivors from the atomic bombings of Japan gather in the auditorium of the Harry S. Truman Library to hear former President Harry S. Truman give a speech. A microphone is on the far left of the photograph. A camera man stands at the front of group filming the speech.  All are unidentified.

title: Group from Japan at Harry S. Truman Library
Scopenote: A group of survivors of the atomic bombings of Japan and others view items on exhibit at the Harry S. Truman Library. All are unidentified.

title: Portrait of Man
Scopenote: An unidentified man poses for a photo in the Harry S. Truman Library, in Independence, Missouri. He was part of a group of survivors of the atomic bombings of Japan that traveled to Missouri to hear former President Harry S. Truman give a speech.

title: Group of Japanese Women
Scopenote: A group of unidentified women sit in chairs at the Harry S. Truman Library. These women were survivors of the atomic bombings of Japan who traveled to the Harry S. Truman Library to hear former President Harry S. Truman give a speech.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman Speech
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman (left) delivers remarks in the auditorium of the Harry S. Truman Library to a group of survivors of the atomic bombs used against Japan in World War II. The man on the right is unidentified.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman at His 80th Birthday Party
Scopenote: Former President Harry S. Truman sits at the head table with his cake at his 80th birthday celebration at the Muehlebach Hotel.  Also in front of him are several telephones and a bank of microphones.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman's 80th Birthday Party
Scopenote: Unidentified guests are seated near the head table at former President Harry S. Truman's 80th birthday party at the Muehlebach Hotel.

title: Former President Harry S. Truman's 80th Birthday
